HDG.LOG.content: logos: Being of beings > [on technology] forgotten lightning-flash of Being emerges as that alone which is worthy of thought [Being of beings has been safeguarded, the beginning of its destiny in Greek thought, still governs modern technology]
HDG.LOG.linkedContent: logos: Being of beings > [on technology] forgotten lightning-flash of Being emerges as that alone which is worthy of thought [Being of beings has been safeguarded, the beginning of its destiny in Greek thought, still governs modern technology]

HDG.LOG.content: [summary of logos as saying/laying] Heraclitus never thought it, dwelt in it though [Derrida’s describing/declaring] > Greeks thought language as vocalization, phonē, phonetically [phono-logocentrism]
HDG.LOG.linkedContent: [summary of logos as saying/laying] Heraclitus never thought it, dwelt in it though [Derrida’s describing/declaring] > Greeks thought language as vocalization, phonē, phonetically [phono-logocentrism]

HDG.BC.content: Greeks as the earliest: originality/bindingness for our history, impending historical decisions: we name the “earliest” the incipient (das Anfängliche) > remembrance of inception can transport us into essential [many/herd misconstrues essential power, fails to hear]
HDG.BC.linkedContent: Greeks as the earliest: originality/bindingness for our history, impending historical decisions: we name the “earliest” the incipient (das Anfängliche) > remembrance of inception can transport us into essential [many/herd misconstrues essential power, fails to hear]

HDG.BC.content: must know Greek language [authenticity] [but Heidegger against phony cultural inheritance] > knowledge of Greek no proof that he can think acc. the thought
HDG.BC.linkedContent: must know Greek language [authenticity] [but Heidegger against phony cultural inheritance] > knowledge of Greek no proof that he can think acc. the thought

HDG.BC.content: elucidation of what the Greek word says to us is not lacking [?] > German language: suited like no other for translating ancient Greek
HDG.BC.linkedContent: elucidation of what the Greek word says to us is not lacking [?] > German language: suited like no other for translating ancient Greek

HDG.BC.content: for inception of our history [contra will of modern technology], for Greeks, decline was unique, momentary, laudable, great > decline of unique vs. perishing, clinging fast to the ordinary > what is imperishable [indestructible] in inception: rarity/singularity of each varied return of what is originary w/in it > experience of inception: realize what essentially came to be known at inception itself > the thought-worthy [value]
HDG.BC.linkedContent: for inception of our history [contra will of modern technology], for Greeks, decline was unique, momentary, laudable, great > decline of unique vs. perishing, clinging fast to the ordinary > what is imperishable [indestructible] in inception: rarity/singularity of each varied return of what is originary w/in it > experience of inception: realize what essentially came to be known at inception itself > the thought-worthy [value]

HDG.BC.content: we hear Greek thinkers, must think about fact that everything has to do w/ us [imperative of hermeneutics of facticity]
HDG.BC.linkedContent: we hear Greek thinkers, must think about fact that everything has to do w/ us [imperative of hermeneutics of facticity]

HDG.BC.content: no timeless rule in meleta to pan, remembering what is incipient and deciding what is yet to come, must single out the Greek thought as 1st beginning, but not as a rule [how is this distinction made?]
HDG.BC.linkedContent: no timeless rule in meleta to pan, remembering what is incipient and deciding what is yet to come, must single out the Greek thought as 1st beginning, but not as a rule [how is this distinction made?]

HDG.BC.content: Greek thinking never asked why unity or en essential feature of Being (pre-Platonic)
HDG.BC.linkedContent: Greek thinking never asked why unity or en essential feature of Being (pre-Platonic)

HDG.WM.content: a history of nothing: from Greek [?] ex nihilo nihil fit (from nothing, nothing comes to be) to Christian dogma ex nihilo fit—ens creatum (from nothing comes—created being) (nothing indicates fundamental conception of beings [here, as counterconcept to summum ens, God as ens increatum?]) > God & nothing [Augustine]
HDG.WM.linkedContent: a history of nothing: from Greek [?] ex nihilo nihil fit (from nothing, nothing comes to be) to Christian dogma ex nihilo fit—ens creatum (from nothing comes—created being) (nothing indicates fundamental conception of beings [here, as counterconcept to summum ens, God as ens increatum?]) > God & nothing [Augustine]

HDG.IWM.content: Greek already ontotheological > metaphysics always has twofold character, but closed off to reason/origin of twofold, it is what it is: representation of beings as beings > metaphysics has no choice: metaphysics by its very essence excluded from experience of Being
HDG.IWM.linkedContent: Greek already ontotheological > metaphysics always has twofold character, but closed off to reason/origin of twofold, it is what it is: representation of beings as beings > metaphysics has no choice: metaphysics by its very essence excluded from experience of Being

HDG.QB.content: from early period of Greek civilization to recent period of our century, “being” has meant: presencing (Anwesen) [not for you?] > every presence (Praesenz) stems from Ereignis of presence (Anwesenheit) [which way to read this genitive?]
HDG.QB.linkedContent: from early period of Greek civilization to recent period of our century, “being” has meant: presencing (Anwesen) [not for you?] > every presence (Praesenz) stems from Ereignis of presence (Anwesenheit) [which way to read this genitive?]

HDG.FS.content: that opposite of monde means impure (immonde) preserves something of Heraclitus’ “world” > fundamental relation of Greek language to nature: leaving nature open in its radiance (Strahlenden) vs. modern era: making nature’s appearances easily calculable
HDG.FS.linkedContent: that opposite of monde means impure (immonde) preserves something of Heraclitus’ “world” > fundamental relation of Greek language to nature: leaving nature open in its radiance (Strahlenden) vs. modern era: making nature’s appearances easily calculable

HDG.FS.content: when Heidegger first attempts to exit prison of consciousness (in Being and Time), not restoring realism against idealism: realism (assurance a world exists for subject) dependent on Cartesianism [Heidegger attempting to think Greek sense of egō]
HDG.FS.linkedContent: when Heidegger first attempts to exit prison of consciousness (in Being and Time), not restoring realism against idealism: realism (assurance a world exists for subject) dependent on Cartesianism [Heidegger attempting to think Greek sense of egō]

HDG.FS.content: logos as gathering, “projects itself toward things that appear in their gathering” > for Greek thought, presencing of human is opening inception for oppositional presencing of World > alētheia: encounter (Begegnung) btwn that which presences and being is a self-opening, welcomes (Empfang) presence [a site, Ort?] > alētheia can’t be translated as truth
HDG.FS.linkedContent: logos as gathering, “projects itself toward things that appear in their gathering” > for Greek thought, presencing of human is opening inception for oppositional presencing of World > alētheia: encounter (Begegnung) btwn that which presences and being is a self-opening, welcomes (Empfang) presence [a site, Ort?] > alētheia can’t be translated as truth

HDG.FS.content: what sort of positing is that by which Absolute appears for consciousness? > in Greek, positing is thesis, apothēkē means same as apophansis, let matter stand here from itself, as it is, i.e. presences (anwest) > modern positing, however, is closest to Latin repraesentatio, the re- refers back to ego cogito, re- as “back to me,” thus that which stands becomes object (all this covered over by presumptions of idealism)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: what sort of positing is that by which Absolute appears for consciousness? > in Greek, positing is thesis, apothēkē means same as apophansis, let matter stand here from itself, as it is, i.e. presences (anwest) > modern positing, however, is closest to Latin repraesentatio, the re- refers back to ego cogito, re- as “back to me,” thus that which stands becomes object (all this covered over by presumptions of idealism)

HDG.FS.content: perception as aisthēsis [?] > “with the Greeks, and precisely in the distinction btwn aisthēsis and noēsis, hell has already begun” > in perception what presences is “bodily (leibhaftig)” [vs. positing, thesis, of representation], chair, flesh
HDG.FS.linkedContent: perception as aisthēsis [?] > “with the Greeks, and precisely in the distinction btwn aisthēsis and noēsis, hell has already begun” > in perception what presences is “bodily (leibhaftig)” [vs. positing, thesis, of representation], chair, flesh

HDG.FS.content: Heidegger agrees with Wittgenstein [?]: “the real is what is the case” [no longer Greek experience of beings]
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Heidegger agrees with Wittgenstein [?]: “the real is what is the case” [no longer Greek experience of beings]

HDG.FS.content: experience of beings, for Greeks, so rich, so concrete, significant synonyms: ta phainomena, what shows itself from itself; ta alētheia, what is revealed (Offenbare) in unconcealment (Unverborgenheit), what postpones (verweigert) concealment for a time
HDG.FS.linkedContent: experience of beings, for Greeks, so rich, so concrete, significant synonyms: ta phainomena, what shows itself from itself; ta alētheia, what is revealed (Offenbare) in unconcealment (Unverborgenheit), what postpones (verweigert) concealment for a time

HDG.FS.content: for Greeks, phenomenon is the thing in itself (an abyss btwn Aristotle & Kant) > unity of ta onta and ta phainomena impossible for Kant > the being has become an ob-ject (res obstans), expression “object” has no correlate in Geek
HDG.FS.linkedContent: for Greeks, phenomenon is the thing in itself (an abyss btwn Aristotle & Kant) > unity of ta onta and ta phainomena impossible for Kant > the being has become an ob-ject (res obstans), expression “object” has no correlate in Geek

HDG.FS.content: Hegel obstructs access (Zugang) to Greek meaning of being from ground up when he claims Greeks had yet to think subjective as mediation, i.e. as core (Kern) of objectivity > Hegel excludes himself from Greek experience of being as phenomenon
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Hegel obstructs access (Zugang) to Greek meaning of being from ground up when he claims Greeks had yet to think subjective as mediation, i.e. as core (Kern) of objectivity > Hegel excludes himself from Greek experience of being as phenomenon

HDG.FS.content: Greeks lived immediately in openness of phenomena—through expressly ek-static capacity of letting phenomena speak to them (modern man, via Descartes, only talks to himself, human as representer), no Greek word for being of human in alētheia, not due to lack, but due to excess > belonging to alētheia as Greek destiny: moira
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Greeks lived immediately in openness of phenomena—through expressly ek-static capacity of letting phenomena speak to them (modern man, via Descartes, only talks to himself, human as representer), no Greek word for being of human in alētheia, not due to lack, but due to excess > belonging to alētheia as Greek destiny: moira

HDG.FS.content: [why the Greeks? philosophy only able to emerge among Greeks?]
HDG.FS.linkedContent: [why the Greeks? philosophy only able to emerge among Greeks?]

HDG.FS.content: difficult to accomplish anew what Greeks did when they thought Being as an appearing outside concealment (phusis), still we ask: what occurs in fact of arising-into-alētheia? > the overabundance (Überfülle), the excess (Übermass) of what presences (Anwesende), thus why Thales can only look to the heavens, relation to this thrust of presence is thaumazein [wonder] [height & excess] > in extreme opposition, when astronauts landed on moon, moon as moon disappeared, only a calculable parameter (Rechnungsgrösse) for technological enterprise of humans
HDG.FS.linkedContent: difficult to accomplish anew what Greeks did when they thought Being as an appearing outside concealment (phusis), still we ask: what occurs in fact of arising-into-alētheia? > the overabundance (Überfülle), the excess (Übermass) of what presences (Anwesende), thus why Thales can only look to the heavens, relation to this thrust of presence is thaumazein [wonder] [height & excess] > in extreme opposition, when astronauts landed on moon, moon as moon disappeared, only a calculable parameter (Rechnungsgrösse) for technological enterprise of humans

HDG.FS.content: Greek philosophers, more Greek than Greek, asked question of being but not question of alētheia as such > question concerning being as being never been posed (gestellt)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: Greek philosophers, more Greek than Greek, asked question of being but not question of alētheia as such > question concerning being as being never been posed (gestellt)

HDG.FS.content: how does Platonic idea (eidos) correspond to what Greeks named presence, ousia, the most extreme excess? for Plato, to change, to alter oneself (sich ändern): abwesen (to absence)—idea as pure presence, never absencing, self-maintaining-making-present, presencing presence (anwesende Anwesenheit) as what’s there in excess, ontos on (Nietzsche had strong sense of this, Twilight of…)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: how does Platonic idea (eidos) correspond to what Greeks named presence, ousia, the most extreme excess? for Plato, to change, to alter oneself (sich ändern): abwesen (to absence)—idea as pure presence, never absencing, self-maintaining-making-present, presencing presence (anwesende Anwesenheit) as what’s there in excess, ontos on (Nietzsche had strong sense of this, Twilight of…)

HDG.FS.content: “the being” for Plato understood in verbal sense (das Seiend) rather than nominal (das Seiende) > determinations of phainesthai and alēthes fully presented in eidos > nothing less Greek than Schopenhauer’s take on Plato (desert exists thanks to my thinking)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: “the being” for Plato understood in verbal sense (das Seiend) rather than nominal (das Seiende) > determinations of phainesthai and alēthes fully presented in eidos > nothing less Greek than Schopenhauer’s take on Plato (desert exists thanks to my thinking)

HDG.FS.content: thinking alētheia as alētheia of logos barred Greeks from thinking alētheia as a-lētheia, as unconcealment, as clearing > in Greek, naming always already signifies making a proposition [Aussagen], make something known as something [Greeks went astray w/ why they thought about language?]
HDG.FS.linkedContent: thinking alētheia as alētheia of logos barred Greeks from thinking alētheia as a-lētheia, as unconcealment, as clearing > in Greek, naming always already signifies making a proposition [Aussagen], make something known as something [Greeks went astray w/ why they thought about language?]

HDG.FS.content: for Hölderlin, to name is to call (Rufen), not to make a proposition > [unpoetic nature of Greek interpretation of language exposed, no higher poetry than in Greece!] > conception of saying (Sagens) as proposition (Aussagen) prevents access to essence of poetry
HDG.FS.linkedContent: for Hölderlin, to name is to call (Rufen), not to make a proposition > [unpoetic nature of Greek interpretation of language exposed, no higher poetry than in Greece!] > conception of saying (Sagens) as proposition (Aussagen) prevents access to essence of poetry

HDG.FS.content: destruction, strong sense of de-struere, Ab-bauen (“dis-mantling”), not devastation (Verwüsten) > destruction strives to free original meaning of Being, this original meaning is presence (Anwesenheit), governs all Greek understanding of being (w/out its knowing it) [presence worthy of the name?]
HDG.FS.linkedContent: destruction, strong sense of de-struere, Ab-bauen (“dis-mantling”), not devastation (Verwüsten) > destruction strives to free original meaning of Being, this original meaning is presence (Anwesenheit), governs all Greek understanding of being (w/out its knowing it) [presence worthy of the name?]

HDG.FS.content: in Greek, theōria means residing (Sichaufhalten) in gaze (Erblicken) of being; today, theory is a programming? program: Anzeige (indication), vorausgreifende Festlegung (anticipatory establishment), Mitteilung einer Planung (communication of a plan)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: in Greek, theōria means residing (Sichaufhalten) in gaze (Erblicken) of being; today, theory is a programming? program: Anzeige (indication), vorausgreifende Festlegung (anticipatory establishment), Mitteilung einer Planung (communication of a plan)

HDG.FS.content: negative (Nichten) vs. denying (Verneinen): Greek distinction ouk and mē? > negating as Greek ouk, then nothing as total nothingness (nihil negativum): beings denied, there are no beings > negating via mē, certain defect re: being > but if being/nothing are same, nothing can’t signify a lack (Fehlen), negating not privative-negative, something other (etwas Anderes), completely specific/unique (ganz und gar Eigenes und Unvergleichliches)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: negative (Nichten) vs. denying (Verneinen): Greek distinction ouk and mē? > negating as Greek ouk, then nothing as total nothingness (nihil negativum): beings denied, there are no beings > negating via mē, certain defect re: being > but if being/nothing are same, nothing can’t signify a lack (Fehlen), negating not privative-negative, something other (etwas Anderes), completely specific/unique (ganz und gar Eigenes und Unvergleichliches)

HDG.FS.content: thinking Ereignis w/ concepts of Being, history of Being, won’t be successful, nor w/ assistance of the Greek (something “to go beyond” [Nietzsche on Socrates]) > Mit dem Sein verschwindet auch die ontologische Differenz [w/ Being, ontological difference vanishes: i.e. Ereignis goes beyond both?]: ontological difference (1927-1936) a necessary impasse (Holzweg)
HDG.FS.linkedContent: thinking Ereignis w/ concepts of Being, history of Being, won’t be successful, nor w/ assistance of the Greek (something “to go beyond” [Nietzsche on Socrates]) > Mit dem Sein verschwindet auch die ontologische Differenz [w/ Being, ontological difference vanishes: i.e. Ereignis goes beyond both?]: ontological difference (1927-1936) a necessary impasse (Holzweg)

HDG.FS.content: no destinal (geschickliche) epoch of Ereignis: sending is from enowning (Das Schicken ist aus dem Ereignen) > return to Greeks only has meaning as a return to Being [?] > “step back (Schritt züruck)” (step that retreats [züruckgeht] from metaphysics [overcoming metaphysics]) has sole meaning of enabling (ermöglichen) glance ahead (Vorausblick) to what comes (was kommt) [to-come], thinking begins anew: in essence of technology thought catches sight of heralding portent (verdeckenden Vor-Schein), die verbergende Vor-Erscheinung des Ereignisses selbst
HDG.FS.linkedContent: no destinal (geschickliche) epoch of Ereignis: sending is from enowning (Das Schicken ist aus dem Ereignen) > return to Greeks only has meaning as a return to Being [?] > “step back (Schritt züruck)” (step that retreats [züruckgeht] from metaphysics [overcoming metaphysics]) has sole meaning of enabling (ermöglichen) glance ahead (Vorausblick) to what comes (was kommt) [to-come], thinking begins anew: in essence of technology thought catches sight of heralding portent (verdeckenden Vor-Schein), die verbergende Vor-Erscheinung des Ereignisses selbst

HDG.FS.content: no “what stands against” in Greek, no Gegenstand, no “object,” only that which, from itself, presences
HDG.FS.linkedContent: no “what stands against” in Greek, no Gegenstand, no “object,” only that which, from itself, presences

HDG.FS.content: scholastic word objectum is translation of Greek word antikeimenon, but keisthai of antikeimenon means already lying before > whereas object, via representation, brought to halt in an “over and against (im Gegenüber)” > Greek experience of already lying before (and from itself) doesn’t require representation play role in positing being > Aristotle interprets phusis from poiēsis, bringing-forth into open—not modern notion of production (set into availability [Herstellen in die Verfügbarkeit])
HDG.FS.linkedContent: scholastic word objectum is translation of Greek word antikeimenon, but keisthai of antikeimenon means already lying before > whereas object, via representation, brought to halt in an “over and against (im Gegenüber)” > Greek experience of already lying before (and from itself) doesn’t require representation play role in positing being > Aristotle interprets phusis from poiēsis, bringing-forth into open—not modern notion of production (set into availability [Herstellen in die Verfügbarkeit])

HDG.FS.content: in Greek manner, einai means to presence (Greeks speak more revealingly (zeigender)/precisely than we do) [Heidegger’s bias?] > Parmenides’ esti gar einai, genuine tautology: names Same only once, as itself: [fragment 8] “the same dwelling in the same, it lies in itself” [cf. 80 verse is eukuklos, abundant/overflowing, says on its own complete tautology] > in domain of inapparent (Unscheinbaren): presencing itself presences (anwest Anwesen selbst): “great number of indications (Zeignisse) [marks? traces?]…”, indication as sēma, what shows & lets be seen
HDG.FS.linkedContent: in Greek manner, einai means to presence (Greeks speak more revealingly (zeigender)/precisely than we do) [Heidegger’s bias?] > Parmenides’ esti gar einai, genuine tautology: names Same only once, as itself: [fragment 8] “the same dwelling in the same, it lies in itself” [cf. 80 verse is eukuklos, abundant/overflowing, says on its own complete tautology] > in domain of inapparent (Unscheinbaren): presencing itself presences (anwest Anwesen selbst): “great number of indications (Zeignisse) [marks? traces?]…”, indication as sēma, what shows & lets be seen

HDG.FS.content: the thinking here [Greek thought]: tautological thinking: primordial sense of phenomenology, prior to any distinction btwn theory/praxis > in philosophy there are only paths (Wege), in sciences only methods > to understand phenomenology: path that leads away to come before…, “lets that before which it is led show itself”: a phenomenology of the inapparent > now you can understand: there were no concepts for Greeks
HDG.FS.linkedContent: the thinking here [Greek thought]: tautological thinking: primordial sense of phenomenology, prior to any distinction btwn theory/praxis > in philosophy there are only paths (Wege), in sciences only methods > to understand phenomenology: path that leads away to come before…, “lets that before which it is led show itself”: a phenomenology of the inapparent > now you can understand: there were no concepts for Greeks

HDG.DL.content: w/ first experience of phenomenon, Greeks didn’t press present beings into opposing objectness (Gegenständigkeit) > phainesthai: a being assumes its radiance (Scheinen), in which it appears (erscheinen) > Das Erscheinen (appearance) still Grundzug of Anwesen von Anwesende, as [beings] rise into unconcealment (Entbergung) ——Heidegger doesn’t think appearance in Greek or Kantian sense > but, what’s decisive (ankommt) [arrival?] is difficult, calls (verlangt) for simple/free vision (Blick)
HDG.DL.linkedContent: w/ first experience of phenomenon, Greeks didn’t press present beings into opposing objectness (Gegenständigkeit) > phainesthai: a being assumes its radiance (Scheinen), in which it appears (erscheinen) > Das Erscheinen (appearance) still Grundzug of Anwesen von Anwesende, as [beings] rise into unconcealment (Entbergung) ——Heidegger doesn’t think appearance in Greek or Kantian sense > but, what’s decisive (ankommt) [arrival?] is difficult, calls (verlangt) for simple/free vision (Blick)

HDG.DL.content: to think Greeks in even more Greek manner doesn’t mean better than them: great thinking understands itself best, i.e. understands itself, w/in limits set for it (zugemessenen Grenzen) > to think more originally than Greeks: to think the unthought clearing (Lichten), the occurrence (Ereignis) [?] of emergence (Hervorkommen) into openness (Lichte) [?], unconcealedness (appearance of that which is present)
HDG.DL.linkedContent: to think Greeks in even more Greek manner doesn’t mean better than them: great thinking understands itself best, i.e. understands itself, w/in limits set for it (zugemessenen Grenzen) > to think more originally than Greeks: to think the unthought clearing (Lichten), the occurrence (Ereignis) [?] of emergence (Hervorkommen) into openness (Lichte) [?], unconcealedness (appearance of that which is present)

HDG.DL.content: no answer will help us, must see (erblicken) appearance as reality (Wesen) of presence (Anwesen) in its essential origin (Wesensherkunft) [no refutation of Greek thought]
HDG.DL.linkedContent: no answer will help us, must see (erblicken) appearance as reality (Wesen) of presence (Anwesen) in its essential origin (Wesensherkunft) [no refutation of Greek thought]

HDG.DL.content: grace, Anmut, Greek charis, which is called tiktousa (brings forward & forth), like German word dichten, tihton > graciousness as the poetical, das Quellen der Botschaft des Entbergens der Zwiefalt
HDG.DL.linkedContent: grace, Anmut, Greek charis, which is called tiktousa (brings forward & forth), like German word dichten, tihton > graciousness as the poetical, das Quellen der Botschaft des Entbergens der Zwiefalt

HDG.WL.content: since the Greeks, beings (Seiende) experienced as what is present (Anwesende) > since language is, the speaking that occurs belongs to what is present [phono-logocentrism]
HDG.WL.linkedContent: since the Greeks, beings (Seiende) experienced as what is present (Anwesende) > since language is, the speaking that occurs belongs to what is present [phono-logocentrism]

HDG.WL.content: if to know means to see something in wholeness of its nature, we can’t see the nature of language as such, in the round, because we belong w/in Saying, can only say something by saying it after Saying > language is monologue [cf. MONL], has its structure in the Aufriss of Saying: 1) language alone speaks authentically 2) language speaks lonesomely (einsam) > the some in lonesome, the same, Greek hama, Gothic sama, thus lonesome: “same in what unites that which belongs together” > Saying is in need of being voiced in word [Being needs man] > man’s needed usage (Brauchen), his resaying (Nachsagen) of what he listens to, lies in that lack (Fehlen) that isn’t negative or defective
HDG.WL.linkedContent: if to know means to see something in wholeness of its nature, we can’t see the nature of language as such, in the round, because we belong w/in Saying, can only say something by saying it after Saying > language is monologue [cf. MONL], has its structure in the Aufriss of Saying: 1) language alone speaks authentically 2) language speaks lonesomely (einsam) > the some in lonesome, the same, Greek hama, Gothic sama, thus lonesome: “same in what unites that which belongs together” > Saying is in need of being voiced in word [Being needs man] > man’s needed usage (Brauchen), his resaying (Nachsagen) of what he listens to, lies in that lack (Fehlen) that isn’t negative or defective

HDG.EC.content: desert is wasteland, deserted abandonment (Verlassenheit) of all life, nothing can emerge from itself [Greek physis] in this wasteland, & in this emergence (Aufgang) call others into a co-emerging (Mitaufgehen) > no perishing (Untergehen) in this desolation
HDG.EC.linkedContent: desert is wasteland, deserted abandonment (Verlassenheit) of all life, nothing can emerge from itself [Greek physis] in this wasteland, & in this emergence (Aufgang) call others into a co-emerging (Mitaufgehen) > no perishing (Untergehen) in this desolation
